baseline completion: ill inmates are housed in Miami before trial. MIAMI, Florida (CNN) -- The ninth floor of the Miami-Dade pretrial detention facility is dubbed the "forgotten floor." Here, inmates with the most severe mental illnesses are incarcerated until they're ready to appear in court. Most often, they face drug charges or charges of assaulting an officer --charges that Judge Steven Leifman says are usually "avoidable felonies." He says the arrests often result from confrontations with police. Mentally ill people often won't do what they're told when police arrive on the scene -- confrontation seems to exacerbate their illness and they become more paranoid, delusional, and less likely to follow directions, according to Leifman. So, they end up on the ninth floor severely mentally disturbed, but not getting any real help because they're in jail. We toured the jail with Leifman. Monday.

The polyps were considered small, Stanzel said, adding that Bush is expected to be released from the hospital by Tuesday.

prompt: SAN FRANCISCO, California (CNN)  -- A magnitude 4.2 earthquake shook the San Francisco area Friday at 4:42 a.m. PT (7:42 a.m. ET), the U.S. Geological Survey reported. The quake left about 2,000 customers without power,
original watermarked completion:
some of whom had to wait in long lines to get assistance, and caused cracks around a couple of homes, but the damage appears to be minimal, according to the USGS.

The strongest shaking in the Bay Area came in the Richmond-San Rafael zone, a bit north of the city, according to USGS geophysicist Carl Anderson. The San Francisco Bay area, with the exception of the East Bay, got the most shaking at magnitude 3.0.

Several people were taken to a hospital in Oakland with injuries. There were no immediate reports of major damage to homes or businesses.

The earthquake was about 7.8 miles below the surface. The epicenter was about 10 miles north of San Francisco.

The USGS said the earthquake was in the same vicinity as a magnitude 4.2 quake on January 23, 2011.

prompt: WASHINGTON (CNN) -- There is "no remaining hope" of finding six men trapped for almost a month in a Utah coal mine alive, a federal official said Saturday. Isaac Arellano holds a candle and sings during a fundraiser for miners Tuesday in Price, Utah. "Over the past 25 days, the Mine
original watermarked completion: Safety and Health Administration has been thoroughly working to locate the six miners. They have done everything possible to locate them and bring them to safety. They are not in any condition to be rescued. It is with great sadness that I have to announce the failure of the search," said James MacDonald, the acting assistant administrator for mine standards and inspection with the Bureau of Mines, in a press release issued Saturday. original watermarked completion:
, central Algeria.

The bomb was attached to a car.

The car carrying the bomb was detonated on a road in front of a police checkpoint, an Interior Ministry official told CNN.

No one was immediately able to confirm the report.

prompt: (CNN) -- A virus found in healthy Australian honey bees may be playing a role in the collapse of honey bee colonies across the United States, researchers reported Thursday. Honey bees walk on a moveable comb hive at the Bee Research Laboratory, in Beltsville, Maryland. Colony collapse disorder has killed millions of bees
original watermarked completion:
in America in recent years and scientists think this virus may be to blame.

The research team found antibodies in the honey bees of 10 colonies in Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia. The researchers said they believe these antibodies are part of a large population that died.

"There is no reason to believe that these beekeepers infected with this virus have not passed it onto their colonies," study researcher Dr. Kent Lawler of the University of Maryland told reporters.

Scientists believe the virus may be the cause of colony collapse disorder. It occurs when a large number of bees suddenly die and the remaining colony can no longer feed itself.

The virus is a large, airborne parasite that causes the bees to die in large numbers. It doesn't affect other bees in the hive, they just die as a group.

The researchers reported their findings Thursday in the journal Nature.

The virus has been reported across the United States and the researchers have no idea where it came from.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture says honey bees are responsible for pollinating $15 billion worth of crops each year in the United States. More than 90 fruits and vegetables worldwide depend on them for pollination. Signs of colony collapse disorder were first reported in the United States in 2004, the same year American beekeepers started importing bees from Australia. The disorder is marked by hives left with a queen, a few newly hatched adults and plenty of food, but the worker bees responsible for pollination gone. The virus identified in the healthy Australian bees is  Israeli Acute Paralysis Virus (IAPV) -- named that because it was discovered by Hebrew University researchers. Although worker bees in colony collapse disorder vanish, bees infected with IAPV die close to the hive, after developing shivering

Although worker bees in colony collapse disorder vanish, bees infected with IAPV die close to the hive, after developing shivering

prompt: LAGOS, Nigeria (Reuters) -- Nigeria's television survival show has been suspended after a contestant drowned in preparation for the program, said Dutch brewer Heineken's local unit which is sponsoring the show. Anthony Ogadje, 25, and nine other contestants had gone to Shere Hills Lake in Nigeria's
original watermarked completion:
commercial hub Lagos to swim in the reservoir before the show, he said. "I started swimming and they told me to come back when I felt ready," Ogadje said in an interview with Reuters in Lagos. prompt: (CNN) -- A former government contract employee was indicted on charges of stealing restricted nuclear energy-related materials and putting the United States at risk, the Department of Justice announced Thursday. Sources say the classified materials were taken from the East Tennessee Technology Park. Roy Lynn Oakley, 67, of Roane County, Tennessee
original watermarked completion: , faces a maximum sentence of life in prison if convicted. Oakley served in the Tennessee National Guard from 1967 to 1973. He worked as a contractor for Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) as a communications technician in 1976-1977. He then worked as a maintenance contract employee from 1979 to 1982. Oakley was a contractor with the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission until June 16, 1991. He then worked as a contractor with ORNL as a maintenance contract employee until January 1, 2003. He was an assistant to the chief of staff of ORNL. The indictment says Oakley stole cables for the nuclear industry and the Defense Threat Reduction Agency. He was also accused of taking other related items. The indictment says Oakley moved the items from his home to a storage facility in Rhea County, Tennessee and placed them on his property in August 2003. He later gave the items to the U.S. Department of Energy. The indictment says Oakley also placed the items on his property

Thomas will be demoted to the rank of entry-level private and will receive a bad-conduct discharge. The 25-year-old was among seven Marines and a Navy medic who were charged in connection with the death of Hashim Ibrahim Awad, 52. The Marines accused in the case were members of Kilo Company, 3rd Battalion, 5th Marine Regiment. They reported at the time that Awad planned to detonate a roadside bomb targeting their patrol. But several residents of Hamdaniya, including relatives of the victim, gave a different account, prompting a criminal investigation. Prosecutors accuse the group's squad leader, Sgt. Lawrence G. Hutchins III, of dragging Awad from his home, shooting him in the street and then making it look like he had planned to ambush American troops. Hutchins has pleaded not guilty to murder, conspiracy and other charges in the case

baseline completion: advertising so far among presidential contenders. The cost to try to influence the 2008 election could exceed $3 billion, according to TNS Media Intelligence/Campaign Media Analysis Group, CNN's consultant on political television advertising. This is nearly twice as much than what was spent in 2004 when political and issue-advocacy television advertising rang in at $1.7 billion. In 2006, $2.3 billion was spent on political and issue-advocacy TV commercials. prompt: (CNN) -- Explorer Dennis Schmitt found an island nearly two years ago near Greenland. Fishermen pass by Greenland's Ilulissat fjord in this September 2004 picture. Such a discovery would usually elicit curiosity, even wonder perhaps, but it evoked mixed feelings for the explorer. The island was once
original watermarked completion:
home to a thriving community that he helped rescue from famine and disease. But the town was abandoned in the 1980s and now Schmitt has found the remains of a town.

(CNN) -- With his hands and feet shackled and his face obscured by his long hair, Chester Arthur Stiles made his initial court appearance in Las Vegas, Nevada, on Wednesday morning on charges stemming from the videotaped rape of a 2-year-old girl.

Stiles, 25, of Reno, Nevada, was seen wearing a white jail jumpsuit and reading a statement in English to the judge before his initial appearance.

The child, seen in the video on Dec. 12, was able to be heard crying out in the video from Stiles' residence.

The child was rescued by detectives in mid-December after a tipster notified law enforcement about footage that showed the child being sexually assaulted, according to an arrest report.

Stiles and the child's mother are now being treated separately at University Medical Center in Las Vegas

Hashim Amla and Jacques Kallis shared an unbeaten stand of 159 as South Africa stretched their lead to 287.
